There was a co-organized Kansas Land Valley Co. They made a contract with the Dominion Government to settle in 20 acres in every township. The land would be sold at $1 per acre. Land besides the town limits was available. The settlers could pay $5 per acre to get 160 acres.

Free homesteads and advantages in all newspapers in United States and Canada. My mother, my mother-in-law, and my half-brother came by her own means. She had been home weeks earlier when we landed in Davidson County on September 19, 1893, and when we arrived at the county, she had all the provisions needed to take us and our horses for two days. We had a good time camping out ahead of a cloud on the plains. We followed a little prairie trail for 25 miles until we stopped living near about 95 to 400 men. We had a little settlement moved in that in Dec., 1903, and the first settlers moved in over 6 hours to get there. Then it was dark night, and we had to stay in the open. There was a co-operative farmstead in Sand Valley.

We made a contract with the Dominion Government to settle in 20 acres in every township. The land would be free from taxes for five years.

Besides the land, we would also receive free homesteads, and advertised in all newspapers in United States and Canada.

My mother, who was then 70 years old, came from Kansas City with her son, one of the passengers home to see his family.

This car landed on December 3rd, 1903, and when we arrived at the farm, we had all the provisions needed to take us until the country. We had 9 days' worth of food.

We started out about 3 o'clock in the afternoon and followed a little prairie trail for 85 miles. We were about 95 to 100 miles north of the settlement.

The first settlers moved in that in June, 1903, and we were the second. We had seven families in the settlement.

The snow and we pounded many days in olden days.

Everybody was living in tents and so did we. One night the end of June a big storm came up and blew our tent to pieces. The only way we could do it's get into a wagon box turned it upside down and lived in that and then we had to make a fire for heat.

Then we had to build a sod house and then we tore down that slumber house. In the fall we placed up a little tree and built a fence around for the winter. We'd near every body done the same thing. Then nobody knew how the winters would be. The first five years we hauled our firewood from the Sandhills, Nebraska and dry wood buying for the last fifteen years.

For two years 1906 we built a little log house and most of those old timers lived there. I'm not sure when they came in and we sure was obliged to see them coming. It didn't matter where you went you was always welcome had to have a lunch when you got off.
The snow and we pounded Mud Cakes in a short time. Everybody was living in tents and so did we. One night the end of June a big storm came up and blew our tent to pieces. The only way we could do it was to get an oxen box turned up side down and used it as a shelter. Then we had to make smoke for heat. Then we began from us, every lady went without her clothes on and everybody stood naked.

Next we had to build a sod house then and there. We tore down that little shack which was 14 by 24 feet and build a little house. In the fall we placed up a little tree and buried them around for the winter. Nobody knew what they were doing. Then nobody knew how the next year would be. The first year we built our house from the ground up. We used dry wood for the first 10 years or more, maybe five years. Then we used pine for the next 10 years.

For 2 years 1906 we build a little house and most of those old timers lived outside. Now my oldest neighbor is 80 and I'm 75 years old. But in 1906 lots more people came in and we were obliged to see them coming. It didn't matter where they came from, always welcome and to have a friend when ever you left.
Our post office was Davidson. There was a prairie trail gone by my house and to everybody stopped in or either stayed overnight.

We lived all over from here to the River and Elmo. The old frontier was all gone but one old one. Early Randel was to stop with me all the time when we went to Davidson and we would work together. We were truly lonesome long trips took us 6 hours to get in and out.

When we traveled instead to Davidson we were sleeping all in one car in the hay loom on the livery barn until back home next day. One farmer bought 1905 in the fall the first threshing machine 4 on north of Elmo to be used in the Hall county from Elmo to Amraville way in too the winter of course. The only had 30 to 60 acres it was stocked. In 1908 we got our Railroad through her to Oakland. Our school 4 on East of Lorclure.
